urls.title: Newsroom - Greenway Polymers Incident moves towards 'recovery'
urls.description: A large-scale fire that started at Greenway Polymers in Telford on April 26, is now under control with partners working towards the recovery phase. Image dated: 12 May 2021 - scroll down for video update. Results from air quality tests around the site, have shown that risks to health are ‚Äòlow‚Äô and no asbestos has been found. Telford & Wrekin Council have been monitoring air quality on a daily basis using equipment from the Environment Agency EA and analysis of data by Public Health England (PHE) Midlands.

text: @ian59047468 @Soulgirl999 @shropsfire @EnvAgency @StaffsFire @HWFire @HighwaysWMIDS This latest release includes a video about what is happening on site and should give you a good idea of what's going on: https://t.co/xEr3vD9OD1

entity.description: Stories are shared of the people, places and issues at the heart of the British countryside. Popular features include the programme's photography contest, which culminates in a yearly calendar sold to benefit charity, the Video Diary, produced by viewers and focused on life in rural areas, and the weather forecasts.

entity.name: Countryfile Diaries
entity.description: A sister show to the BBC's `Countryfile' series, this rural affairs programme sees a team of presenters travel the length and breadth of the United Kingdom to cover stories related to the British countryside and the season of spring. As this period is a busy time of the year for the farming and outdoor communities in particular, regular topics covered include the production of food, nature conservation, and a look at a chosen area's culture and history. Stunning landscapes and a variety of wildlife also feature prominently.

urls.title: High levels of E.coli detected in Port Meadow swimming spot | Cherwell
urls.description: As the weather warms, lockdown restrictions begin to lift, and students return to Oxford for Trinity Term, outdoor activities, including wild swimming, are on the rise. Students have been taking to the banks of Port Meadow for picnics, and some are venturing into the water of the River Thames. This idyllic summer image, however, is [‚Ä¶]

text: RT @Jamesxparsons: An assessment by @EnvAgency of the Wye, estimates the chief source of pollution (~60%+) is agricultural and waste water‚Ä¶

Yesterday's @BBCCountry file reminded us yet again that it's the citizen scientists @FriendsUpperWye  who now seem responsible for monitoring the health of our rivers. The re-funding of our water regulators @WaterNRW @EnvAgency so they can do their job properly is such a priority https://t.co/dtvvPPQb9P
